Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 51305-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2017 
 
 
Republic of Kazakhstan: Joint Government of 
Kazakhstan and the Asian Development Bank 
Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, 
Phase 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
 
Policy 2011.
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

(as of 9 November 2017)

$1.00  =  T333.76 
 
ABBREVIATIONS

ADBI    –  Asian Development Bank Institute

Committee

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  Sean O’Sullivan, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Country Director  Giovanni Capannelli, Kazakhstan Resident Mission (KARM), CWRD 
   
Team leader  Zhanat Murzakulova, Economist, KARM, CWRD

territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) is the third phase of the Joint 
Government of Kazakhstan and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Knowledge and Experience 
Exchange Program (KEEP).1 The TA will support the delivery of demand-driven, just-in-time, 
analytical, and technical knowledge products and services to Kazakhstan. It will help bring 
international best practices to the country, introduce innovations, and enhance the capacity of 
staff working for the Government of Kazakhstan and related agencies. 
 
2.  The TA will also support the implementation of ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS), 
2017–2021 for Kazakhstan,2 which emphasizes the importance of enhancing the country’s 
knowledge  base  to support socioeconomic  development. The  CPS  recommends  that  ADB 
expand collaboration on knowledge sharing and capacity development under the KEEP, implying 
the provision of policy advice and capacity building to enable the government to design and 
implement better informed policies and reforms in priority areas. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Since 1991 when Kazakhstan became independent from the former Soviet Union, the 
country has transitioned from a low-income to an upper middle-income country, according to 
World  Bank  classifications.  In  nominal  dollar  terms,  the  country’s  gross  domestic  product 
increased fivefold, from $24.9 billion in 1991 to $133.7 billion in 2016, positioning Kazakhstan as 
the largest economy in Central Asia. Commensurate improvements in household income and 
welfare accompanied this rapid economic expansion. The gross domestic product per capita 
increased from $1,512 in 1991 to $7,510 in 2016, and the share of the population below the 
national poverty line declined from 36.0% in 1996 to 2.7% in 2016.3 
 
4.  While Kazakhstan’s economic growth achievements are noteworthy and commendable, 
they are based primarily on expanding oil production and historically high global energy prices 
prior to 2015. Kazakhstan’s oil production tripled during between 2000 and 2014, when global oil 
prices reached record-high levels, and the ensuing windfall revenues both ensured sufficient fiscal 
space for social expenditures and endowed state-owned enterprises with resources for massive 
capital investment.  
 
5.  The 2007–2008 global financial crisis and the external shocks that hit the country in late 
2014 in relation to the lowering of international commodity prices revealed the following structural 
vulnerabilities in Kazakhstan’s economic model: (i) a poorly diversified economy highly dependent 
on export revenues from hydrocarbons, and the concentration of foreign direct investment in 
natural resources; (ii) underdeveloped infrastructure, especially outside the cities of Astana and 
Almaty; (iii) the pronounced vulnerability of the finance sector; (iv) the low degree of competition 
in the economy, restraining the development of the private sector; and (v) growing environmental 
risks, with a large share of the economy vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.4  
 
6.  Recognizing the country’s emerging knowledge needs, in 2013, ADB and the government 
established the KEEP through a memorandum of understanding (MOU), which provides the 
program’s overall framework by outlining its objective and scope, areas of focus, implementation 
                                                
1  Each phase of the program is being financed with separate TA, jointly financed by ADB and the government. 
2  The ADB Board of Directors approved the CPS, 2017–2021 for Kazakhstan on 12 September 2017. 
3  The year 1996 is the earliest available data point for statistics on the national poverty line. 
4  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Kazakhstan, 2017–2021. Manila.

2 
arrangements, and monitoring and evaluation measures. The MOU also commits the parties to 
cost-share a range of activities during program implementation.5  
 
7.  Initially, the KEEP was to be articulated in three phases for a total of $2,500,000, financed 
equally by ADB and the government. However, given Kazakhstan’s strong demand for knowledge, 
by 2015, actual commitments and disbursements had already exceeded the indicative amounts 
in the MOU. Accordingly, the MOU was updated in April 2015 with a supplementary agreement 
to ensure greater flexibility and responsiveness to government needs. Moreover, to reflect the 
additional  commitments  included  in  the  2017–2021  CPS  to  meet  increasing  demand,  in 
September 2017 the government and ADB agreed to update the MOU further, extending its 
validity until December 2019, revising contributions accounting for increased financing, and 
refining its strategic focus. The updated and indicative KEEP financing plan for 2013–2019 is in 
Table 1.6  
 
Table 1: Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program Financing Plan  
($)  
Asian Development  Government of 
Year  Total Financing   Bank  Kazakhstan 
Phase 1 (2013–2015)  500,000  250,000  250,000 
Phase 2 (2015–2017)  1,000,000  500,000  500,000 
Phase 3 (2017–2019, indicative)  2,000,000  1,000,000  1,000,000a 
Total  3,500,000   1,750,000   1,750,000  
a  By  November  2017,  the  Government  of  Kazakhstan  had  contributed  $500,000  to  Phase  3,  and  is  
expected to contribute an additional $500,000 in 2018.  
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
8.  The  pilot  phase  was  implemented  through  the  policy  and  advisory  TA,  the  Joint 
Government of Kazakhstan and ADB KEEP, Phase 1, which was approved in July 2013 and 
completed in December 2016.7 ADB and the government each provided $250,000. As a joint 
committee established under the 2013 MOU, ADB and the government scrutinized and approved 
project proposals from government agencies channeled through the Ministry of National Economy 
(MNE). The TA project supported 10 subprojects: six analytical studies and four capacity-building 
activities. At the TA’s closing date, 99.95% of the funds were disbursed. The KEEP, Phase 1 was 
rated successful upon completion.  
 
9.  Given the growing number of government agencies requesting knowledge support under 
the KEEP, in late 2014 the MNE and ADB jointly agreed to design and implement the Joint 
Government of Kazakhstan and ADB KEEP, Phase 2.8 On 24 July 2015, ADB approved Phase 2 
for a total of $1 million, financed equally by ADB and the government. The expected completion 
date is 31 March 2018. To date,  Phase 2 has supported five completed and six ongoing 
subprojects with overall commitments for $1,142,730, awarded contracts worth $399,144, and 
disbursements for $301,234. 
 
                                                
5  The MOU between the government and ADB was signed on 5 June 2013. 
6  ADB and the government are currently discussing a second supplementary agreement to the MOU that is expected 
to be finalized by the middle of December 2017. 
7  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to Kazakhstan for the Joint Government of Kazakhstan and the Asian Development 
Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, Phase 1. Manila (TA 8414). 
8  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to Kazakhstan for the Joint Government of Kazakhstan and the Asian Development 
Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, Phase 2. Manila (TA 8933).

3 
 
10.  Based on feedback received from the MNE during the revision sessions, and lessons from 
implementation during the first two program phases, the implementation of the KEEP, Phase 3 
will incorporate the following actions: 
(i)  ADB and the government will formulate and implement a monitoring and evaluation 
mechanism built according to mutually agreed accounting standards, including 
frequent portfolio meetings to ensure timely corrective interventions, if needed, and 
improved flexibility;  
(ii)  ADB and the government will finalize an indicative list of potential subprojects, 
preferably within 1 month after the knowledge and support TA is approved—the 
list will include standby projects to allow financing on a first-come, first-served 
basis; and 
(iii)  the TA project team will coordinate closely with ADB’s Operations Services and 
Financial Management Department to ensure expeditious consultant recruitment 
in the case of urgent subprojects involving short-term assignments (less than 30 
working days) and relatively small and simple subprojects in terms of disbursement 
(i.e.,  those  with  a  budget  of  less  than  $30,000  involving  only  consultants’ 
remuneration and travel expenses).9  
 
11.  To ensure the delivery of high-quality knowledge products and services under the KEEP, 
Phase 3, it is important that experienced ADB and ADB Institute (ADBI) staff are involved in all 
stages of TA implementation, from identifying potential subprojects to monitoring and supervising 
their  delivery.  In  this  regard,  the  TA  team  will  consult  closely  with  relevant  divisions  and 
departments at ADB headquarters and ADBI to encourage the provision of quality staff inputs and 
ensure that such inputs are adequately recognized.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: achieving a more competitive and inclusive 
economy, developing human capital, and enhancing the country’s institutions and governance 
systems.10 The TA will have the following outcome: high-quality policy research through enhanced 
government capacity and awareness of best practices achieved.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
13.  The  main TA  outputs will  fall  under  the  categories  of  policy  advisory  and  capacity 
development, including (i) policy research reports submitted, and (ii) capacity-building activities 
and learning events delivered. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
                                                
9 This action is based on the need to ensure an adequate response to the government’s emerging needs. Under the 
KEEP phases 1 and 2, individual consultants were recruited within 1.5–2.0 months, on average, from the time that 
the recruitment notices were published on ADB’s website to the signing of the contracts. Some assignments 
requested by the government were short-term and associated with the urgent need to develop government 
documents (including concepts, proposals, and draft laws) within tight deadlines, requiring timely responses from the 
previous KEEP TA projects. 
10  Official Site of the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan. Address by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, 
Leader of the Nation, N.A. Nazarbayev on Strategy “Kazakhstan-2050”: New Political Course of the Established State. 
http://www.akorda.kz/en/addresses/addresses_of_president/address-by-the-president-of-the-republic-of-
kazakhstan-leader-of-the-nation-nnazarbayev-strategy-kazakhstan-2050-new-political-course-of-the-established-
state (accessed 15 November 2017).

4 
14.  Output 1: Policy research reports submitted. In 2017–2019, the TA will produce at 
least eight bilingual policy research reports that will serve as background materials for the 
government’s policymaking, and submit them to the relevant government agencies by 2019. The 
KEEP Coordinating Committee (KCC) will assess the achievement of this activity and present the 
results in the annual KCC activity reports. The KCC secretariat will confirm a list of analytical 
subprojects with the MNE, and prepare the terms of reference (TOR) for consultants who will 
conduct respective studies. In addition, the KCC secretariat will convene four dissemination 
workshops to discuss the main research results during the TA implementation period. 
 
15.  Output 2: Capacity-building program delivered. Four to six capacity-building events for 
government and related agencies’ staff will be conducted in 2017–2019 and reflected in the TA 
reports. The KCC secretariat will confirm the planned capacity-building subprojects with the MNE 
before devising the TOR for the consultants who will be in charge of the actual implementation of 
the respective capacity-building activities.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will finance Phase 3 of the KEEP. The TA budget is estimated at $1,500,000. ADB 
will finance $1,000,000, and the government will finance up to $500,000. The TA will follow the 
same reimbursable approach adopted for phases 1 and 2, based on which ADB will allocate the 
total amount of $1,500,000 from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), 
where the government has already transferred its $500,000.11 The cost estimates and financing 
plans are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over a 24-month period starting in January 2018. The MNE 
will be the TA executing agency. ADB will be responsible for supervising and monitoring the TA 
activities (Table 2). The ministries or agencies responsible for initiating the specific subprojects 
will be the respective implementing agencies. ADB, through its Kazakhstan Resident Mission and 
the assistance of a program coordinator, will support the TA administration. The TA proceeds will 
be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from  time to time).  Counterpart  staff  at  ADB  headquarters will  contribute  to the 
management of the subprojects, where necessary. The KCC, which comprises representatives 
from the MNE and ADB Kazakhstan Resident Mission, will oversee the implementation of the 
KEEP, Phase 3.

Upon the completion of this transfer, this amount can be used to increase the TA budget to a total of $2,000,000.

5

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
18.  The monitoring of the TA will be results-oriented. A main measurement of subproject 
outcome will be whether the government uses the recommendations emanating from the TA. The 
KCC will carry out the monitoring through its secretariat, which will coordinate closely with all 
agencies carrying out the subprojects and ensure that issues are dealt with as they arise. Under 
the KCC’s overall direction and guidance, the secretariat will prepare quarterly progress reports 
and a TA completion report. The final evaluation of the TA will be based on the performance 
indicators outlined in the design and monitoring framework. 
 
19.  The KCC will disseminate good practices and lessons learned through reports and 
workshops, as well as ADB and government websites. The KCC will see to it that these good 
practices and lessons are adequately reflected in subsequent KEEP subprojects, and relevant 
government and ADB projects. 
 
20.  Consulting  services.  ADB  will  engage  consulting  firms  and  individual  consultants 
following ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Disbursements will be in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The TA will use an estimated 60 person-months of national and 30 person-months of international 
consulting inputs to support research, workshops, and other agreed subproject activities. The 
nature of the needed expertise and inputs will be determined case by case for each activity or 
subproject determined and approved jointly by the MNE and ADB. The inputs of consultants as 
well as short-term resource persons will serve to introduce international best practices; provide 
in-depth local knowledge; and advise on policy options, challenges, and the implications of 
various  courses  of  action.  The  selection  method  for  consultants  will  be  chosen  during 
implementation depending on what is best suited to the respective TOR. All consultants and 
experts will be engaged based on their expertise and proven experience in the subproject areas. 
The detailed TOR for consultants, including duration and expected results, will be discussed and 
prepared as soon as ADB and the MNE finalize and clear the proposed subprojects. The KCC 
will coordinate with ADB departments to engage the most experienced ADB and/or ADBI staff in 
the implementation of the subprojects.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a reimbursable 
basis, as discussed in para. 16, to the Government of Kazakhstan for the Joint Government of 
Kazakhstan and the Asian Development Bank Knowledge and Experience Exchange Program, 
Phase 3, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
